Developing Identifiers.title: Developing Identifiers for Heritage Collections
Developing Identifiers.content:
This resource describes the different facets of developing persistent identifiers (PIDs) in the context of Heritage Collections. This resource is aimed at senior technical stakeholders within galleries, libraries, archives and museums to assist with developing requirements and advocacy for new services.

[##]

This resource will be revised in 2021 and maintained until the conclusion of the Towards a National Collection programme in 2025. Comments and discussions are welcome, as are additional examples

Augment.title: Augment with existing identifiers
Augment.content:
Externally-created persistent identifiers are included for items and entities within metadata

Explanation

PIDs such as Wikidata IDs, ISNIs, Getty URIs, DOIs, Gazetteer URIs and IDs from other collections can be added to collection management systems. These can be included for related collection items, an identifier for a collection item itself where it is represented in another identifier scheme and authority files.

Benefits

  • Links with other collections.
  • Reduces workload of creating institution specific authority files.

Example

The Library of Congress provides links to other identifiers in its names identifier file.[http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79041870|http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79041870]

National Galleries Scotland and Moma in New York integrate Getty ULAN records and Wikipedia data into their artistsâ€™ web pages. [https://www.nationalgalleries.org/art-and-artists/artists/paul-gauguin|https://www.nationalgalleries.org/art-and-artists/artists/paul-gauguin] [https://www.moma.org/artists/5047|https://www.moma.org/artists/5047]

Dependencies

Baseline required.

Compatible PID Types

  • Wikidata IDs
  • Getty URIs
  • Gazetteer URIs
  • Digital Object Identifiers from other collections
  • Handles from other collections
  • ARKs from other collections
  • URIs from other collections

For more compatible identifiers, see Which persistent identifier does what?
